etymologies: Middle English; earliest use found in Genesis and Exodus. From classical Latin decima tenth part, offering of a tithe made to a god, tax or right to collect a tax of ten per cent on the produce of land, in post-classical Latin also (in the Old Testament) tithe (Vulgate), tithe paid to the Christian Church, (in music) interval of a tenth, use as noun (short for decima pars tenth part) of feminine of decimus tenth

definitions: A tenth part; specifically a tax of one tenth, a tithe. Now historical (chiefly with reference to Italy).
In Spanish poetry: a stanza or verse of ten lines, usually performed as a song.

notes.text: The song typically consists of four stanzas, with an introductory verse.

definitions: An organ-stop sounding a tenth above the normal or 8-feet pitch; also called double-tierce or great-tierce.
